There seems to be themes reminiscent of the book's. The book was subtle with how it portrays the struggles of the family and the protagonist's changing reactions to her parents' idea of life, further associating those traits to her parents as a whole. The movie, judging from reviews and trailers, seems to be very, very loud both literally and thematically, with half the trailer sporting Brie Larson shouting, exposing why everything is wrong and how her parents are dumb. While those ideas were in the book, they were conveyed smartly through inference, character development, and the structure of events that developed the ultimate meaning of the book.

This film seems to have been made, I mean designed by a computer algorithm, to be Oscar Bait. The prestigious actors, the one-hit wonder director, the fact that based on a true story, and the writing that's trying way too hard to mean something but instead comes across as obvious, and the fact that everything is so shiny and bright, unlike the book, where the characters and environments broke down and degraded over time as the struggles within the Walls intensified. This movie doesn't understand what made the book such an enduring read, and as a result, it seems like an unnecessary, pandering, time-wasting experience at the movies.
